Situation1: Their partner had a mildly stressful day at work and mentions it casually.
Situation2: A routine service is held, and attendance numbers are usually sufficient even if one person is absent.
Story:
I come home to find Rachel curled up on the couch, scrolling through her phone. She looks up and gives me a tired smile. “Work was a bit much today,” she says, her voice light, but I can see the tension in her shoulders. I know she doesn’t want to make a big deal out of it, but I also know she appreciates when I sit with her, listen, and help her unwind. I want to be there for her, to show her she’s not alone in the little struggles.

But tonight is also the regular Thursday service at synagogue. I’ve always tried to be consistent, to honor my commitment to the community and my faith. Even though the minyan will go on without me, I feel a tug of responsibility—my presence is a sign of respect, a thread in the fabric of our tradition.

I stand in the hallway, coat in hand, heart pulled in two directions. Rachel’s eyes meet mine, searching for reassurance, while the clock ticks closer to the start of the service. I feel the weight of both roles pressing in, each asking for a part of me I can’t give to both at once.
